Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: The radio crackled with urgency as I scanned the radar, watching the cloud tops surge higher than forecasted. Pilots’ voices overlapped, each waiting for my revised climb instructions. My headset felt heavier than usual, pressing against my ears as I tried to keep my voice steady and clear. The clock on the wall glowed 10:55 a.m.—five minutes until the church service started. I was supposed to be there, sitting in the third pew, singing hymns and joining the congregation in prayer. My pastor had reminded me last week how important it was to be present, to show commitment not just in faith but in fellowship. But here I was, tethered to my console, responsible for the safety of dozens of lives in the sky. My heart pounded with guilt and anxiety, torn between the sacred call to worship and the urgent duty to guide these planes through the rising storm. I stared at the radar, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which voice I should answer first.
